head.title: Roses in El Salvador's Garden of Good and Evil

hedline.hl1: Roses in El Salvador's Garden of Good and Evil

abstract.p: Juliet Popkin letter on July 11 article recalls shock over slaying of six Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter in El Salvador in 1989 helped bring end to nation's civil war

block.p: Re ''Pilgrims Take Inspiration From Martyrs of the 80's'' (San Salvador Journal, July 11):
Re ''Pilgrims Take Inspiration From Martyrs of the 80's'' (San Salvador Journal, July 11):

With my daughter Margaret, a human rights lawyer who had worked for six years as the deputy director of the University of Central America's Human Rights Institute, I stood in the garden at the university several months after the killing of six Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter in 1989.

It was a brilliantly sunny morning, and the gardener was attending to the lawn. Quietly, my daughter pointed out six red rose bushes and two yellow ones that had been planted in memory of the martyrs. Then she told me that the gardener was the husband and father of the two slain women.
Human rights issues continually bombard us from all over the world, but these tragic deaths shocked so many that they brought an end to a terrible civil war. The work of justice remains.
Instead of spending billions on weapons and weapon defenses, why doesn't our nation initiate a vast effort toward peace, justice and human rights?
JULIET POPKIN Pacific Palisades, Calif. July 11, 2000
